results.abstract: Dylan Loeb McClain chess column on American astronaut Greg Chamitoff playing chess aboard International Space Station against opponents in mission control; diagram; photo (M)

headline.main: Space Station to Mission Control: It's Your Move

results.snippet: Greg Chamitoff, an American stationed aboard the International Space Station, has managed to find time for a few games of chess.
results.lead_paragraph: The crew members aboard the International Space Station are busy, but Greg Chamitoff, the American astronaut currently stationed there, has managed to find time for a few games of chess. Chamitoff boarded the station this spring as part of the mission to install a new Japanese experiment module, a laboratory for conducting research in space.

results.abstract: The chess column for Sunday, Sept. 7, is about Greg Chamitoff, an American astronaut aboard the International Space Station, who has been playing chess games with mission control. As the column mentions, this is not the first Earth vs. space chess match. In June 1970, Soviet astronauts Andrian Nikolayev and Vitaly Sevastyanov, who were aboard [...]
results.snippet: The chess column for Sunday, Sept. 7, is about Greg Chamitoff, an American astronaut aboard the International Space Station, who has been playing chess games with mission control. As the column mentions, this is not the first Earth vs. space chess...
results.lead_paragraph: The chess column for Sunday, Sept. 7, is about Greg Chamitoff, an American astronaut aboard the International Space Station, who has been playing chess games with mission control. As the column mentions, this is not the first Earth vs. space chess match. In June 1970, Soviet astronauts Andrian Nikolayev and Vitaly Sevastyanov, who were aboard the Soyuz 9 spacecraft, played a consultation game against the earthbound Viktor Gorbatko, another astronaut, and Nikolai P. Kamanin, a Soviet general who was the head of the astronaut training program. Miron Sher, a grandmaster and coach who lives in New York City, dug up the score of the game. It can be replayed below.

results.snippet: Many rock bands have a moment when they flirt with cinema. The Oklahoma group the Flaming Lips do so with “Christmas on Mars.”
results.lead_paragraph: Many rock bands have a moment when they flirt with cinema. The Oklahoma group the Flaming Lips do so with “Christmas on Mars.”

byline.original: By JEANNETTE CATSOULIS, NATHAN LEE, NEIL GENZLINGER, ANDY WEBSTER and LAURA KERN

results.abstract: K Ingemar Jonsson of Kristianstad University, Sweden, leads study on tardigrades, tiny invertebrates that live in water, that finds they are able to survive space conditions; research, which is published in journal Current Biology, tested tardigrades in vacuum-only conditions and full spectrum and intensity ultraviolet radiation; drawing (M)

headline.main: Water Bears Triumph Over Outer Space

results.snippet: Tardigrades, creatures commonly called water bears, can survive in space, researchers have discovered.
results.lead_paragraph: For as long as humans have dreamed about spaceflight, they have also had nightmares about the perils of space. There's the cold vacuum, of course, which can freeze-dry an unprotected astronaut. There are other hazards, too, including the sun's ultraviolet rays, unfiltered by atmosphere. Being exposed to them is no day at the beach -- it's far worse. Too bad we all can't be tardigrades, those tiny roly-poly invertebrates that live in lakes and oceans and among mosses and lichens. European researchers report that these creatures, commonly called water bears, can survive in space.

results.abstract: Joan D Winston, legendary fan of Star Trek television series, dies at age 77; photo (M)
results.snippet: For the ''Star Trek'' faithful, it was a historic event. Gene Roddenberry, the creator of the series, showed up. So did the science fiction writer Isaac Asimov, not to mention fans dressed as Klingons, Tribbles and Bele from the planet Ceron. NASA...
results.lead_paragraph: For the ''Star Trek'' faithful, it was a historic event. Gene Roddenberry, the creator of the series, showed up. So did the science fiction writer Isaac Asimov, not to mention fans dressed as Klingons, Tribbles and Bele from the planet Ceron. NASA delivered a scaled-down lunar module and a spacesuit. It was January 1972, and the first Star Trek convention was under way in a rented ballroom at the Statler Hilton in Manhattan. The organizers had expected a crowd of about 500. In the end, more than 3,000 fans turned up, so many that by the final day of the event registrars were issuing ID cards made from torn scraps of wrapping paper. For fans of the series, the convention marked the moment when a diaspora became a nation.

results.abstract: Tens of thousands of residents return to Galveston, Tex, to see what remains of their homes two weeks after Hurricane Ike; those who live behind city's seawall can remain; those not behind seawall can clean their property but must leave each night; NASA changes launch date of space shuttle Atlantis from Oct 10 to Oct 14 to compensate for week of training and preparation lost after Hurricane Ike; photos (M)

headline.main: Galveston Residents Allowed to Return to Their Battered City

results.snippet: As Nadine Hernandez rode across the causeway to this battered island on Wednesday morning, she began to cry at the sight of Hurricane Ike's destruction -- the boats scattered here and there, the downed palm trees, the damaged homes.     And even...
results.lead_paragraph: As Nadine Hernandez rode across the causeway to this battered island on Wednesday morning, she began to cry at the sight of Hurricane Ike's destruction -- the boats scattered here and there, the downed palm trees, the damaged homes. And even though one of her sons had told her that her three-bedroom house had been decimated by the storm surge, she cried again while putting on a mask to go inside.

results.abstract: China's Shenzhou VII spacecraft blasts off, taking three Chinese astronauts into space; three-day mission, China's third manned space mission in five years, is expected to include country's first attempt at spacewalk; photo (M)

headline.main: China Sends Three Into Space in the Nation's Third Manned Mission in Five Years

results.snippet: The three-day mission by the Shenzhou VII spacecraft is expected to include the country’s first attempt at a spacewalk.

byline.original: By DAVID BARBOZA; John Schwartz contributed reporting from New York

results.lead_paragraph: The Chinese Shenzhou VII spacecraft blasted off at 9:07 p.m. Thursday, carrying three Chinese astronauts into space on this country's third manned space mission in five years. The three-day mission is expected to include the country's first attempt at a spacewalk.

results.abstract: A chess match between the Earth and Greg Chamitoff, an astronaut aboard the International Space Station, will begin on Monday, Sept. 29. The Earth will be led by a team of kindergarteners through third graders at Stevenson Elementary School in Bellevue, Wash. The school won the K-3 championship section at the elementary school national championships [...]
results.snippet: A chess match between the Earth and Greg Chamitoff, an astronaut aboard the International Space Station, will begin on Monday, Sept. 29. The Earth will be led by a team of kindergarteners through third graders at Stevenson Elementary School in...
results.lead_paragraph: A chess match between the Earth and Greg Chamitoff, an astronaut aboard the International Space Station, will begin on Monday, Sept. 29. The Earth will be led by a team of kindergarteners through third graders at Stevenson Elementary School in Bellevue, Wash. The school won the K-3 championship section at the elementary school national championships in May.

headline.main: Astronaut From China Takes First Spacewalk for Nation

results.snippet: BEIJING -- A Chinese astronaut orbiting the earth lifted himself out of the Shenzhou VII spacecraft Saturday afternoon and performed the nation's first spacewalk, another milestone in China's space program.     Zhai Zhigang pulled himself out of the...
results.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- A Chinese astronaut orbiting the earth lifted himself out of the Shenzhou VII spacecraft Saturday afternoon and performed the nation's first spacewalk, another milestone in China's space program. Zhai Zhigang pulled himself out of the orbital module about 4:40 p.m. Beijing time, latched himself to a handrail with two safety cords and then waved to a national audience during a live broadcast of the country's third space mission with an astronaut.

results.abstract: Problem with control system on Hubble Telescope that relays data to ground has forced delay of shuttle mission set for launch on Oct 14; Atlantis had been set for 11-day visit to telescope to install new instruments and repair telescope's best camera and spectrograph; mission will be delayed so astronauts can replace failed control unit; flight will not take place before February 2009 (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Mission To Telescope Is Moved to '09

results.snippet: The mission to service the Hubble Space Telescope will be delayed until next year, NASA officials said.
results.lead_paragraph: A problem that struck the Hubble Space Telescope on Saturday will delay the final space shuttle mission to service it, moving the launching from next month to next year, NASA officials said Monday. A crew of seven astronauts was scheduled to blast off in the shuttle Atlantis on Oct. 14 for an 11-day visit to the telescope, which for 18 years has been beaming cosmic postcards to Earth from its orbital vantage point above the atmosphere.
